article_title: Addiction treatment with a dark side
article_text:
Total Access

article_metadata.description: For Shawn Schneider, a carpenter and rock musician, the descent into addiction began one Wisconsin winter with a fall from a rooftop construction site onto the frozen ground. As the potent pain pills prescribed for his injuries became his obsessive focus, he lost everything: his band, his job, his wife, his will to live. Sider was staying in his parents’ basement when he washed down 40 sleeping pills with NyQuil and beer. His father heard him gasping and intervened, a reprieve that led Schneider into rehab. It was not his first program, but the one where he discovered buprenorphine, a substitute opioid used to treat opioid addiction.
